The reason because they are more competitive. Mario Kart Smash bros Mario 
party SA2 Battle The Mario sports games sonic riders and soo much more you 
could add to that. When I mean smooth and polished I'm talking about Frame 
Rate and Graphics. Not the gameplay(while the majority of GameCube games 
have smooth gameplay because we all no if you play Melee competitive i does 
get fast but that's actually why people play melee or project m most 
instead of brawl because their more competitive. The GameCube era is 
actually one of NIntendo's best eras in their company. While al their games 
are really great and competitive and nostalgic, were not defending it 
because of nostalgia.

top_comment.text:
Double Dash also features locations from other games. What about Luigi's 
Mansion on Luigi Circuit? Dry Dry Desert from Paper Mario? And (even though 
it's not a location) Donkey Kong Jr in the crowd of Waluigi Stadium? But of 
course, these are minor details you've missed. This was fantastic to watch. 
Even though I already knew a few of these, it was great to know that there 
were so many more. I really want to go back on DD right now just to see if 
I can find any more.﻿

comments.author: coolguy3DS - Gaming, glitches, and more!

comments.text: In Daisy Circuit (Wii), the Daisy Cruiser can be seen in the distance.
comments.author: Number1KirbyFann

comments.text:
+NintendoTV64 I just remembered that the star-shaped Mario Kart signs in 
Mario Circuit also appear in Sherbet Land, a track that shares its name 
with a track from Mario Kart 64. There's also the Wario's Pharmacy signs 
found throughout Mushroom City, not to mention the Nintendo GameCube 
advertisement found there as well. The ominous mountains surrounding 
Bowser's Castle also appear in Mario Kart Wii's Bowser Castle track, which 
has a similar layout. The pool on the Daisy Cruiser has an image of 
Princess Daisy in it, while the Grand Pianta Statue makes a cameo 
appearance in Peach Beach. The Wario Star advertisement found in Wario 
Coliseum is also found in Mario Kart Wii's Wario's Gold Mine track, and the 
license plates of the vehicles found in Mushroom Bridge and Mushroom City 
make references to several classic Mario games. Lastly, the obelisks in Dry 
Dry Desert feature images of Mario, Luigi, Peach, Yoshi, Donkey Kong, 
Wario, Bowser, and Baby Mario.
comments.author: NintendoTV64

comments.text:
Let's not forget that Wario Coliseum appears to take place within the 
actual Roman Coliseum and offers a view of Mushroom City as well! And the 
Luigi's Mansion battle map obviously takes place within Luigi's Mansion 
itself, complete with pictures of the ghosts from said game. The Birdo 
Watching advertisement from Yoshi Circuit also appears in the previous 
track, Mushroom City. And the Delfino Fruits advertisement also appears in 
Peach Beach. The Wiggler Bus in Mushroom Bridge and Mushroom City is based 
off of the Wiggler boss from Super Mario Sunshine, while several Yoshi's 
Island characters appear in Baby Park, including Poochie, Shy Guy, Baby 
Bowser, Hookbill the Koopa, and Kamek. Finally, there's the Moo Moo Farm 
delivery truck and Peach Beach Bus in Mushroom Bridge and Mushroom City! 
Hope that covers everything!
comments.author: NintendoTV64

comments.text:
Did you notice on Baby Park, the DK Mountain volcano has rainbows around

rainbows are actually in front of DK Mountain, but it's hard to see.

+GameXplain I think he means the giant mushrooms that can be seen in the 
background that resemble the buildings from Mushroom City.
comments.author: NintendoTV64

comments.text:
I looked all over that course, I'm pretty sure you can't see Mushroom City. 
Why do you think you can?
comments.author: GameXplain

top_comment.text: You missed something ﻿
top_comment.author: Mesmo Wiztastic

comments.text: +Marco Azoz The baby mario and luigi
comments.author: Mesmo Wiztastic

comments.text: +Mesmo Wiztastic Which is?
comments.author: Marco Azoz

captions.text:
Hey guys welcome to Cool Bits where we point
out our favorite moments from popular and

maybe not so popular games. These Cool Bits
might be a secret, an Easter Egg, or just

a small detail that really resonated with
us.

This time we'll be taking a look at some neat
background details in Mario Kart: Double Dash
that are easily overlooked.

Okay, so it's not any great secret that Mario
Kart: Double Dash takes quite a bit of inspiration

from Super Mario Sunshine. Of course, there
are the obvious references, such as Toadsworth's

cameo during the award ceremony, and even
an entire racetrack which appears to take

place right on Sunshine's Isle Delfino itself.
Then there are others that are a just a little

more subtle, such as various Mario Sunshine
signs scattered about--including one that's

even bears the graffiti mark of Mario's evil
doppelganger.

So clearly the two games have a lot in common,
and it's really not that surprising when you

consider they were released within about a
year of each other.

But there's still one really cool little detail
that most people probably didn't catch by

itself, but also owes its roots to Super Mario
Sunshine

So one of the cooler details about Super Mario
Sunshine was that the entire game was designed

to appear as if it took place within a single,
connected world, being of course, Isle Delfino.

What this meant was you could often see the
island's landmarks from just about any point

in the game, such as the Volcano that looms
over the entire island.

And beyond that, you could even see levels
that you may not even visited yet from within
entirely different levels in the game.

Take the game's first level, Bianca Hills,
for example. If you turn around at the very

start and look off into the distance, you
might first spot Delfino Plaza, which of course

is the town you just came from. But if you
then zoom the camera out, you'll be rewarded

with a fantastic view of another level far
below:. And if you pan to the right, you'll
get a glimpse of Pinna Park.

And the same holds true for nearly every level
in the game. Such as the aforementioned Pinna

Park, which not only affords a view of all
of the levels we've already mentioned--including

Bianca Hills--but it also provides a glimpse
of Gelato Beach and Sirena Beach.

It's a small detail that's easily overlooked--and
yet it goes a long way in making the world

feel more like a real place. So what's this
have to do with Mario Kart: Double Dash? Well,

that game actually borrows the exact same
concept.

To show you what we mean, let's first head
on over to the Mushroom Cup's Peach Beach,

which fittingly enough, is based on Mario
Sunshine, as we pointed out before.

Now if you've raced on this course before,
then you might have noticed a couple of cruise

ships in the background. Of course, there's
The Sunshine, docked in the harbor. But if

you look out a bit further out into the ocean,
you'll spot another: the Daisy Cruiser. Yep,

the same Daisy Cruiser that you race on in
the Flower Cup. Now that race appears to take

place while out at sea--perhaps it's way to
its next destination?

And that destination might just be the Star
Cup's Yoshi Circuit, as it can also be seen

in the background near the end of the course.
And not only that, but The Sunshine can also

be seen a bit earlier too, so apparently they
follow similar Itineraries. And because it

seems both Peach Beach and Yoshi Circuit are
among the destinations, it might explain why

there's advertising for Isle Delfino can be
found here.

Now cruise ships aren't the only type of vehicle
to appear in this level, as the Yoshi Helicopter

makes an appearance too. Yep, the same Yoshi
Helicopter that also appears in the Mushroom

Cup's Baby Park. So it seems that the background
vehicles really do get around in this game.

Now speaking of Baby Park, there are a ton
of cool details surrounding the racetrack

course, but it's perhaps ironically the mountain-sized
one that's most easily over-looked. After

turning the corner just before the finish
line, you might just notice a frowning volcano

in the far distance. But that's not just any
frowning volcano--as if there could be any

others--oh no, it's actually the very same
volcano featured in the Star Cup's DK Mountain.

And while we're here--pay close attention
to those flames shooting out

Now if we head on over to the Special Cup's
Dino Dino Jungle, you might have spotted some

fiery activity happening far off in the background.
And that's normally all you'd be able to make

of it in a typical race. Although if you take
the time to turn around while on the final

bridge, you'll not only get a better look
at those same flames, but you'll be able to

see that they're emerging from the unmistakable
jagged peak of the grumpy volcano from DK
Mountain.

And in case there were any doubt, the color
of the flames even match perfectly, unlike

every other smoldering peak seen in the game.
Who knew that DK Mountain was so close to

Baby Park and Dino Dino Jungle? Maybe that's
why the Volcanoe's so upset--he's tired of
being recognized all the time

But we're not done recognizing Mario Kart
locations yet! If we head on over to the Flower

Cup's Mushroom Bridge, you might have noticed
some buildings in the far distance across

the water . And if you look even closer, you'll
see that some are even topped with Mushroom-caps.

As it turns out, you're actually looking at
a distant version of the Star Cup's Mushroom

City, where you'll actually race among those
mushroom capped-buildings.

And in case you don't believe us, you can
actually look across that same body of water

from the Mushroom City side of things during
the final bend to spot the unmistakable bridge
of Mushroom Bridge.

And did you know that Mushroom City also doubles
as the true home of the Special Cup's Rainbow

Road, which takes place directly overhead?
You can tell when racing there by the identical

buildings far below, complete with the same
mushroom-topped structures.

Finally, let's head back to Mushroom Bridge
one last time, because this course has the

distinct honor of affording a view of not
just Mushroom City, but one more racetrack

as well. If you look into the foggy distance
just right of the first tunnel, you'll spot

one of the Mushroom Kingdom's most famous
landmarks: Peach's Castle. Yep, the very same
one from the Flower Cup's Mario Circuit.

Who would have guessed that a Mario Kart game
would pay so much attention to fictitious

geography? And it's for that exact reason
that these background details are among some

of our favorite--not only do they pay homage
to Mario Sunshine before it, but they also

stand on their own in offering an unparalleled
sense of making Mario Kart's world feel more

like a real place. And we think that's pretty
darn cool.

And that wraps up this episode of Cool Bits
for Mario Kart Double Dash. Thanks for watching

and make sure to keep an eye on GameXplain.com
for more Cool Bits and other things gaming
too.

title: Cool Bits - Mario Kart: Double Dash's Secret Connected World
